description: Write n in base 9 and juxtapose.
comments: An irregular table in which the n-th row lists the base 9 digits of n. - _Jason Kimberley_, Dec 07 2012The base 9 Champernowne constant: it is normal in base 9. - _Jason Kimberley_, Dec 07 2012
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
mathematica: Flatten@ IntegerDigits[ Range@ 55, 9] (* or *)almostNatural[n_, b_] := Block[{m = 0, d = n, i = 1, l, p}, While[m <= d, l = m; m = (b - 1) i*b^(i - 1) + l; i++]; i--; p = Mod[d - l, i]; q = Floor[(d - l)/i] + b^(i - 1); If[p != 0, IntegerDigits[q, b][[p]], Mod[q - 1, b]]]; Array[ almostNatural[#, 9] &, 105] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jul 01 2014 *)
prog: (MAGMA) &cat[Reverse(IntegerToSequence(n,9)):n in[1..31]]; // _Jason Kimberley_, Dec 07 2012(Haskell)a031076 n = a031076_list !! (n-1)a031076_list = concat $ map reverse $ tail a031087_tabf-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 07 2015
crossrefs: Tables in which the n-th row lists the base b digits of n: A030190 and A030302 (b=2), A003137 and A054635 (b=3), A030373 (b=4), A031219 (b=5), A030548 (b=6), A030998 (b=7), A031035 and A054634 (b=8), this sequence (b=9), A007376 and A033307 (b=10). - _Jason Kimberley_, Dec 06 2012
author: _Clark Kimberling_
